Technological advancements and ever-changing work policies provide people with an option to work from home, rather than the office where they meet the team face to face. List out and discuss the advantages and disadvantages of working from home?

Technology has seen drastic changes. This field has always been emerging and has seen significant growth. The advancements in technology has greatly helped the nations connect with each other. It is no longer confined to using the internet on the computers but it is also advanced to using the mobile internet. Where everything was done manually is now being automated with the usage of technology. Technology is not restricted to usage of internet but it works as a catalyst. Almost every task is carried out through the involvement of technology in one or the other stage. It is an evergreen field and has much scope for further developments. 

The latest advancement of technology is the use of the robotics. These robots respond to people and can move from their place. Roomba Robotics can be another example of robots where the task of cleaning is assigned to the robots through the computer program that is fed to it. The other technology changes can the use of advanced security systems which include eye scanning, finger prints, voice recognition etc. These assure safety to the user.

Another emerging technology advancement is the voice recognition software. Today even companies use the voice recognition softwares to feed the data to the system. This has greatly hepled the companies to save time and energy and the number of people required for perfoming the task. One example of such software can be "Speech to Text" software which accepts the commands according to the speaker and his tone.

The most common advancement seen is the use of internet which is not only accessible through the computer systems but also through mobile phones. The various applications help connect with each other eliminating the distance which would have otherwise been a hindrance. Companies also transfer information through the use of Intranet, Electronic Data Interchange, Extranet etc. There are ofcourse various policies that the companies have to stick to, for the use of such data. Online transactions are also possible through its use. Online Banking services, e-commerce etc. are yet to receive popularity. 

Though technology has shown great signs of growth and helped people connect with each other, it has its own pros and cons. Some of its advantages are as follows-

ADVANTAGES:

1. Faster access to work- Where manual work used to take hours for completion, through the use of technology it has greatly been cut down to seconds. E-mails and online orders can be given as examples.

2. Communication is no longer a barrier. 

3. Reduces the work stress and burden.

4. Technology usage has become mandatory and hence even people from rural areas are encouraged to gain knowledge.

5. It has attracted the FDI and hence many employment opportunities are opened which demand for computer knowledge.

DISADVANTAGES:

1. Reduced face to face communication.

2. Technology, though successfully emerged faces problem in the correction of errors, if any.

3. When it comes to using internet, security is a big cause of worry.

4. Technology upgradation is very necessary for companies. Failure of the same may result in losses.

 

Despite the above mentioned cons, technology has been growing successfully.

June 2013 – Global Auto Industry Outlook

The auto industry is highly concentrated. The top 10 global automakers account for roughly 80% of the worldwide production and nearly 90% of total vehicles sold in the U.S.

In the first five months of 2013, General Motors Company ( GM ) led with a 18.0% market share in the U.S., followed by Ford Motor Co. ( F ) with a 16.4% market share, Toyota Motors Corp. ( TM ) with a 14.2% market share, Chrysler-Fiat with a 11.7% market share, and Honda Motor Co. ( HMC ) and Nissan Motor Co. ( NSANY ) at the last spots with 9.5% and 8.1% market shares, respectively.

Toyota recaptured the sales crown from General Motors by selling 9.75 million vehicles globally in 2012, which exceeded GM`s sales of 9.29 million vehicles. Germany`s Volkswagen AG ( VLKAY ) came third with sales of 9.07 million vehicles for the year.

OPPORTUNITIES

To remain competitive, the automakers will need to design vehicles that will cater to consumers in both mature and emerging markets while manufacturing them at low-cost using the most advanced technology.

For example, Ford has undertaken "One Manufacturing" strategy, which aims at producing multiple models from plants across the world in order to save production costs and fast adaptation to changes in consumer tastes. The automaker anticipates producing 4.5 models at each of its plants by 2015, up from 3.6 models currently.

Further, the automakers are concentrating on offering more optional features (which will save money on gas), even on the small and less gas-guzzler vehicles in order to attract buyers. The sale of optional features is helping them offset lower profit margins for small cars relative to large trucks.

The automakers continue to shift their production facilities from high-cost regions such as North America and the European Union to lower-cost regions such as China, India and South America. According to a study by CSM Worldwide, China and South America together will represent more than 50% of growth in global light vehicle production in the auto industry from 2008 to 2015.

The role of governments is highly significant. Their energy and environmental policies will be strongly responsible in molding the auto industry in the coming years. In late 2011, 13 major automakers, including Ford, GM, Chrysler, BMW, Honda, Hyundai, Jaguar/Land Rover, Kia, Mazda, Mitsubishi, Nissan, Toyota and Volvo, have signed letters of commitment with the U.S. Government to upgrade the fuel economy standard of cars and light-duty trucks to 54.5 miles per gallon (mpg) by 2025.
